title: SS Peel Castle
text:
The passenger steamer SS "Peel Castle" was operated by the <a href="Isle%20of%20Man%20Steam%20Packet%20Company">Isle of Man Steam Packet Company</a> from her purchase in 1912 until she was sold for breaking in 1939.
Construction and dimensions.
Peel Castle was built as "Duke of York" at <a href="Dumbarton">Dumbarton</a> by <a href="William%20Denny%20and%20Brothers">William Denny and Brothers</a>, who also supplied her engines and boilers. She had a registered tonnage of ; length 310 feet; <a href="Beam%20%28nautical%29">beam</a> 37 feet; <a href="Draught%20%28hull%29">draught</a> 16 feet and a design speed of 17 knots.
Peel Castle had accommodation for 1,162 passengers, and a crew of 42.
Pre-war service.
As "Duke of York" she entered service in 1894 on the joint <a href="Fleetwood">Fleetwood</a> - <a href="Belfast">Belfast</a> service of the Lancashire & Yorkshire Railway and the London & North Western Railway. In 1911, she was sold to the "Turkish Patriotic Committee". In 1912 the <a href="Isle%20of%20Man%20Steam%20Packet%20Company">Isle of Man Steam Packet Company</a> purchased her and renamed her "<a href="Peel%20Castle">Peel Castle</a>"; the company also purchased "Duke of Lancaster", renamed "The Ramsey".
War service.
She was requisitioned by the <a href="British%20Admiralty">Admiralty</a> at the outbreak of war in 1914.
She was fitted out as an <a href="Ocean%20boarding%20vessel">Armed Boarding Vessel (ABV)</a> by <a href="Cammell%20Laird">Cammell Laird</a> in late November 1914. She was to have 100 officers and crew and was fitted out as an <a href="auxiliary%20ship">auxiliary</a>, capable of carrying boarding parties and <a href="prize%20crew">prize crew</a>s, and was put under the command of Lieutenant-Commander P. E. Haynes <a href="Royal%20Navy%20Reserve">RNR</a>
"Peel Castle" sailed under the <a href="White%20Ensign">White Ensign</a> in January 1915, her engine room manned mostly by Steam Packet Company personnel, and became part of the Downs Boarding Flotilla, a section of the <a href="Dover%20Patrol">Dover Patrol</a>. She remained with the Patrol for three years and one month.
She would spend ten days at sea and four days in port at <a href="Dover">Dover</a>. She was mainly tasked with regulating the large amount of maritime traffic between the <a href="Kent">Kent</a> coast and the <a href="Goodwin%20Sands">Goodwin Sands</a> and to act as one of the guard ships that would stop and examine all neutral shipping proceeding to Continental ports. For the duration of the war the <a href="Dover%20Strait">Dover Strait</a> was closed by anti-submarine nets and <a href="minefield">minefield</a>s. No ship could pass except through the Patrol, and at one stage British warships were intercepting, searching and marshalling up to 115 vessels a day.
In this strenuous work, "Peel Castle" played a busy and successful part. She was first fired upon by a retreating merchantman, and then at least once by <a href="artillery%20battery">British shore batteries</a>. She endured many air raids and sent boarding parties onto many ships. Her crew captured a number of enemy personnel who were trying to get back to Europe hidden in neutral ships, including <a href="Franz%20von%20Rintelen">Franz von Rintelen</a>, an infamous agent of <a href="Admiral%20Tirpitz">Admiral Tirpitz</a>.
In 1916 she was badly damaged by fire and had to be refitted at <a href="Chatham%2C%20Kent">Chatham</a>. Later she transferred to the <a href="Orkney%20Islands">Orkney Islands</a>. After having been fitted with <a href="depth%20charge">depth charge</a> throwers and <a href="Paravane%20%28weapon%29">paravanes</a> and with her <a href="boat%20deck">boat deck</a> extended as a landing for <a href="kite%20balloon">kite balloon</a>s, she patrolled north of <a href="Shetland">Shetland</a>.
"Peel Castle" was next moved to the Humber-Tyne Patrol, an area where shipping was very concentrated and where losses had been heavy. With her observer aloft in the <a href="Observation%20balloon">balloon</a> she would cruise up and down the <a href="convoy">convoy</a>s, looking for enemy <a href="submarine">submarine</a>s.
The war over, "Peel Castle" was refitted once more, this time as a troop carrier, work she continued until May 1919, after which she returned to <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> and resumed her peacetime Steam Packet Company duties.
Post-war service.
Upon returning to the Steam Packet fleet, "Peel Castle" was mainly used for subsidiary winter services. She undertook the direct Friday sailing from <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> to <a href="Ramsey%2C%20Isle%20of%20Man">Ramsey</a>, and also excursion trips and cargo duties.
On the morning of Saturday 7 June 1924, "Peel Castle" went aground in Douglas Bay. She had left <a href="Port%20of%20Liverpool">Liverpool</a> operating the sailing, and had approximately 550 passengers embarked. As she approached <a href="Douglas%2C%20Isle%20of%20Man">Douglas</a>, "Peel Castle" encountered a bank of <a href="fog">fog</a> which forced her to slow her speed. Steaming at minimal speed, "Peel Castle" continued inbound to <a href="Douglas%20Harbour">Douglas</a>, sounding her <a href="Whistle%23Ships">whistle</a> continuously, but ran <a href="Ship%20grounding">aground</a> on a <a href="Shoal%23Sandbars%20and%20longshore%20bars">bank of sand</a> in the middle of Douglas foreshore. The impact was reported to be so slight that passengers were unaware of the situation until members of the <a href="ship%27s%20company">ship's company</a> informed them of the development.
As the tide receded and the fog began to lift, a large crowd gathered on the shore. Passengers remained on board "Peel Castle" until she refloated. Shortly after the vessel was refloated, aided by the <a href="SS%20Fenella%20%281881%29">"Fenella"</a>, and then proceeded to <a href="Douglas%20Harbour">Douglas Harbour</a> under her own power.
No apparent damage could be seen so "Peel Castle" left <a href="Douglas%2C%20Isle%20of%20Man">Douglas</a> the following day, bound for the <a href="Drydock%23Graving">Graving Dock</a> at <a href="Cammell%20Laird">Cammell Laird's</a> in order to be inspected by representatives of <a href="Lloyd%27s%20of%20London">Lloyd's of London</a>. No damage was found on the subsequent inspection, and "Peel Castle" returned to service.
Disposal.
"Peel Castle" was retired after a service life of 45 years. She was broken up at <a href="Dalmuir">Dalmuir</a> on the <a href="River%20Clyde">Clyde</a> in February 1939.
